reviewText: The hardest roguelike I've ever played, and I love it.  Success is dependant on your own skill during the game's lightning-quick combat.  You must constantly be on alert for the slightest skittering or a heavy footfall, clueing you into the next reanimated monstrosity that's ready to come charging at you around the next corner.  Split-second mistakes can break you easily. The game utilizes a clever and very smooth inventory management system, and mastering it on-the-fly is vital to survival.\n\nA very subtle, yet compelling story builds slowly as you wander through the darkened, shadowy corridors.  The game is thick with a brooding, oppressive atmosphere, steeped in hard sci-fi horror.  Sound design is amazing, and the graphics are impressive for being so deceptively simple.  One of the best indie games I've played - keeps me facing its challenge again and again, even as it brutally beats me back down so often.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
While I was originally drawn by the boast of how difficult Teleglitch was as a rougelike I found myself actually a little disappointed at first as I breezed through the first two levels, slashing and shooting my way through hordes of mutants and zombies who seemed to be rather ineffectual at best.

I wrote the difficult off as exaggeration, much like I did with titles such as Dark Souls, where the difficulty of the game comes down to memorizing patterns until encounters become trivial at best. It was then I was met with level three, which was a life support facility. Aside from a close brush with a sudden horde of 20 or so zombies, things proceeded smoothly.

I then found a secret which lead me to this big sprawling area with a huge button. Being the curious sort I pressed it, and in seconds was torn to ribbons by three rather extremely large red gentlemen with automatic weaponry.

Thus is Teleglitch so far, and it is a rather masterfully done atmospheric game, proving that survival horror themes work well in a roguelike setting. While the game for the most part doesn't really offer anything spectacular, as the current theme likens to a lot of roguelikes where you encounter a new enemy type and then die to it, it does offer promise in it's crafting and item management system.

The only two negatives I have about the game, is that in one, I feel it is not random enough, as indeed there is limited differences in each playthrough I have had so far and the other, being more of a problem with the genre itself, is that sometimes the game just refuses to give you anything useful and then you die.

So if you like roguelikes, give it a whirl, especially if you catch it on sale. But if you are prone to frustration, I'd probably pass.

8/10

reviewText:
Have you ever hungered for a roguelike with a mix of careful planning and fast paced action peppered about? Then maybe Teleglitch is for you. From the very start, you’ll go about the usual roguelike style of killing and progression (no leveling here) and collect various materials which can be crafted into useful items, weapons, and even armor to help you progress through the game.

Combat is a quick and dirty endeavor and typically will be resolved within a few seconds depending on various factors. I found using choke points and blind spots to be the best path to victory, as being able to fully unload on an enemy at point blank range (before they are able to retaliate) is a great recipe for success. I would also highly recommend that you get the detector and EM detector upgrade ASAP as being able to know where enemy swarms come from, as well as the location of entrenched opponents, is absolutely vital to your survival.

Once you get the hang of the overall combat and crafting systems, Teleglitch is a fairly straightforward game that rewards careful planning and precise execution (and punishes recklessness and haste!) It will definitely take you 10 or so deaths before you finally get the hang of the game. But, if you hang in there, you’ll be glad that you did.

It was then I was met with level three, which was a life support facility. Aside from a close brush with a sudden horde of 20 or so zombies, things proceeded smoothly.

I then found a secret which lead me to this big sprawling area with a huge button. Being the curious sort I pressed it, and in seconds was torn to ribbons by three rather extremely large red gentlemen with automatic weaponry.

Thus is Teleglitch so far, and it is a rather masterfully done atmospheric game, proving that survival horror themes work well in a roguelike setting. While the game for the most part doesn't really offer anything spectacular, as the current theme likens to a lot of roguelikes where you encounter a new enemy type and then die to it, it does offer promise in it's crafting and item management system.

The only two negatives I have about the game, is that in one, I feel it is not random enough, as indeed there is limited differences in each playthrough I have had so far and the other, being more of a problem with the genre itself, is that sometimes the game just refuses to give you anything useful and then you die.

So if you like roguelikes, give it a whirl, especially if you catch it on sale. But if you are prone to frustration, I'd probably pass.

8/10

reviewText:
Picked this one up during a sale, and i can honestly say i've never been hooked by a game this quickly. The controls are tight and responsive, the graphics, while minimalist, are very well done, the UI is honestly one of the most intuitive i've ever used, and there's even some very good lore to the game if you're willing to look for it.

The gameplay, while unforgiving, is extremely satisfying for that exact same reason. The enemies in the late game can kill you in a blink of an eye if you're not expecting them, but once you learn to listen for the audio cues they make, it becomes a lot more manageable. Which reminds me, turn your your sound up in this game, it'll make your life exponentially easier.

Overall, Paradox did a very good job with this one. Try to snag it during a sale, but i'd argue that the normal price might even be worth it.

reviewText: The hardest roguelike I've ever played, and I love it.  Success is dependant on your own skill during the game's lightning-quick combat.  You must constantly be on alert for the slightest skittering or a heavy footfall, clueing you into the next reanimated monstrosity that's ready to come charging at you around the next corner.  Split-second mistakes can break you easily. The game utilizes a clever and very smooth inventory management system, and mastering it on-the-fly is vital to survival.\n\nA very subtle, yet compelling story builds slowly as you wander through the darkened, shadowy corridors.  The game is thick with a brooding, oppressive atmosphere, steeped in hard sci-fi horror.  Sound design is amazing, and the graphics are impressive for being so deceptively simple.  One of the best indie games I've played - keeps me facing its challenge again and again, even as it brutally beats me back down so often.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game doesn't kid around. It throws you into a dark, mysterious place full of humanoid creatures trying to annihilate you, with only a few necessary things so you're able to survive at first, with many other items scattered around the facilities and hidden rooms. Teleglitch is a real hard game, and you should experience it yourself.
There's always the same way you start, but the way you progress differs with what you find and what you craft with it. You can craft almost everything you need to stay alive, from meds, through armors to deadly weapons and bombs. The game makes you reconsider your decisions often and economical with what you own, as it tends to be scarce with ammo and other items, so you pretty much need to examine every nook and cranny and decide whether to finish off a group of zombies with a bomb or a few shotgun slugs.
The atmosphere of the game is enigmatic, and you'll often find yourself discovering data logs which uncover more and more about the game's lore. There is no music, but for me, it only makes the game darker. The graphical style is rather simple, but neat, and the glitchy effects look really good. The informations about health, ammo or items you own are short and simple, as well as the interface.
Arm yourself with a lot of patience and time, because you're going to find yourself dying over and over. This isn't the sort of game for the weak, but as earlier mentioned, you should give it a try anyways. There's even a demo so you can easily see if you're prepared for the hordes.

reviewText:
This is a must have if you're into hardcore, permadeath rogue-like genre like me.
The price is a bit high for what the game is, if you're not sure if you want it then wait for a sale/bundle but no matter the price - I think it's definitely worth it.

It's fast paced, it is brutal as hell, it's unforgiving... but most importantly, It's fair in my opinion. If you screw up - it's your fault because the game gives you everything you need to beat it, it's just hard not to screw up at times. One second you're fully stocked on ammo, guns, have a lot of food and medicine... you open the door and an army of hungry and rogue biounits and reactivated organics along with War Walkers and All-Terrain Heavy laser Squidbots charge your position and - if you're lucky - you made it out alive, you find all you have is a few bullets in your heavy rifle - THAT'S when the game begins, and the game is great at doing that.

You have to scavenge, conserve every bullet (I mean it, once you've played it you'll understand after a few dozens of stupid deaths) and constantly be on your guard. Doesn't matter if you're armed to the teeth, you can get screwed by a single encounter.

Pros (keeping in mind the genre of the game, same applies to the cons):
- Hard difficulty but it's fair and the game teaches you everything you need to know in the tutorial and during the gameplay itself.

- Simple yet effective graphic design. Some people might say it looks like crap but I think it looks good, especially when considering the dynamic shadows and the way game renders the walls and light sources.

- Good sound design, it's nothing outstanding but considering it's indie and so and that some of the sounds were sourced from different websites I think it works well, and the sound IS important in this game so keep that in mind.

- Cool level design, it reminds me of games like DOOM or Quake but in 2D, heh.

Cons:
- Enemies. There's nothing wrong about them, really... It's just that you're basically fighting zombies all the way through the game, wish the enemies were a bit more creative. They still have different ranged attacks so at least there's that.

- No way to save middle of the game, no matter what. You unlock save points by beating levels, so let's say you get to level 5 and the game unlocks the start from level 3 for you. Sadly, if you leave middle of the game - tough ♥♥♥♥ - you have to start all over again if you want to play again or use one of the unlockable save points. This really, really sucks in this game because it's God damn hard, so let's say you play for 5 hours, have to leave and close the game - boom, gone. No way to continue from that point :(

- Stupid DLC which doesn't even include the soundtrack into the game, you have to play it in a music player. I'd advise not to buy it, unless you want the soundtrack for whatever reason (Again, it's not in game if you don't buy it so you have no idea what the soundtrack actually is, lol)

All in all, I recommend this game.
Have fun!

reviewText:
As is the case with many games, I bought Teleglitch on a whim and for a few measley bucks. On the surface, it promised me the usual cache of indie-game features: a unique art style, a tried-and-true, marketable gameplay type (roguelikes are all the rage these days) and so on and so on. Imagine, then, my surprise when Teleglitch: Die More Edition turned out to not only be decent, but this year's answer to 2012's fantastic Hotline Miami. Technically, Telegitch was a 2012 release, but this shiny new version adds a host of features that personally, I don't think the game could really live without.

We play as some space marine doing what space marines do best: answering distress calls and blowing things of varying size into as many pixel-y bits as possible. We learn, slowly, that some wacky experiments were going on with teleportation and mutation and blah blah blah, you've heard it before. The story is bland, but well-told through audio logs that mark the first time I've actually stopped to read the darn things. A dark sense of humor certainly helps.

Gameplay is really why we're here though. Teleglitch, as I hinted in a rather blatant manner at, reminds me of last year's incredible Hotline Miami. Mutants don't approach; they charge head-on. Hostiles with guns shoot without stopping to check if perhaps you're friendly after all. Dodge their bullets, and they begin leading their aim. There is very good reason the subtitle of this game implies we're going to die. More.

None of this is a bad thing. This is a challenging game, one I may never see the final level of, but it is so without being unfair. The controls are responsive, your aim is reasonably accurate, and if you're conservative with bullets the first few stages, ammo's never a problem. Nope, every death here is you screwing up, as every death should be. The levels are just randomized enough to keep things interesting, but not so much you run the risk of being unable to defend yourself. You have the tools you need, it's all down to how you apply them.

Visually, Teleglitch is kind of surprising. Screenshots would have you believe this could have come out alongside Doom as a cheap pack-in. In motion, however, this game looks fantastic. It packs a retro feel, sure, but it's overlayed with effects as you explode and shoot and otherwise murder things that warp the pixels around you. This is probably the first time I can actually say post-processing effects really add something to a game, but here they really do. Each bomb and bullet looks as though it's tearing the world apart.

Indeed, Teleglitch: DME puts me in the difficult position of having to admit I can't really think of many faults with something. It falls under the umbrella of that rare caste of games with perfect difficulty, meaningful visual design, and just plain visceral fun. Teleglitch may have run me just over $2 at the time I purchased it, but I think, of all the titles I've given a go this year, it just might be the one I'll keep installed.

reviewText:
Brilliant, cruel and very tense. Essentially what you'd get if you put the real-time shooting back into Doom: The Roguelike. Ten randomly generated floors of sci-fi research complex, and a hojillion monsters, zombies, mutants and robots between you and escape. It's very hard, and it's very good, and kinda terrifying until you get a feel for it.

It's a game of resource management, really. You're always low on ammo, enemies are dangerous, healing is scarce and as you get deeper into the complex, enemies become more resistant to low-caliber firearms, meaning you either have to scavenge carefully or use a basic crafting system to bodge together custom weapons.

The art style can be pretty divisive - it's a concious decision to make things as minimalist as possible while still being visually parseable. Whether it achieves that goal is a point of much debate, but I've never had much trouble with it. The excellent audio (everything has its own audio cue) helps cut through the noise, too.

The Die More edition is a general tweaking, tuning and polishing update. There's a few new weapon types, and five of the levels have alternate exits that lead to 'B-side' version of the next level, giving it a little more replay value.

Totally worth it, especially as it's on sale right now.

reviewText:
I recommend this game if you enjoy it's art style.  Because if you don't, you'll get sick of it fast.  Environments vary little for the first half of the game, and you're going to be stuck there for a while.  I still haven't beaten it, but I like Teleglitch.  I just wish there was more than one kind of environment.

Gameplay is frenetic, intense, slow, and crazy in intervals.  The action has a kind of lethal tempo that it's visual style helps accentuate elegantly.  Audio is minimalistic, effective at evoking atmosphere, and occasionally frightening.

The game does want to eat you.  Those interested should give it a try if they can catch it on sale, but only veterans of the rogue-like genre should consider it at full price.  /Opinion

Bottom Line:  I'm personally giving this game a full recommendation.    If you've like what I and others have to say about it, get it.

reviewText: Teleglitch: Die More EditionA small lonely planet on the edge of habitable space is the site of a shadowy research facility specializing in necrotic tissue reactivation. You are a scientist who has suddenly awoken to the realization that you are the lone survivor.he rest of the facility’s personnel have all been killed – micro-chipped and reactivated as combatants by the facility’s central processing AI.\n\nStoryWe are scientist on the small dark planet pretty far than real world, as scientist we are working on super unlimited Teleporter what can teleport people whatever they want, also we are making military weapons and lots of monsters" what would be userful in the war. reviewText: Not bad. Some of the negative reviews would make you think that this game will kill your family or something, so I was skeptical, but it's just a regular a-hole style roguelike. You're going to die a lot and a good deal of the time there's nothing you can do about it. It's not fair, but it's not supposed to be. If you want to win you're going to need a lot of luck tempered by skills forged in the fire of your repeated failures.\n\nIf you don't like the sound of that then play something else.
voteText: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Even if you don't particularly care for the RogueLike genre, This just might be up your alley. The atmosphere is pretty moody between the lighting and the ambient effects, And the difficulty level seems to be constant without any major spikes in difficulty. There's even a delicious combining system so the creative players can craft useful tools of survival off of what they find lying around.\n\nI would honestly say this is the nethack of Roguelike shooters so far..!

reviewText: Tense atmosphere, edge-of-your-seat gameplay, an interesting take on retro-graphics, and  a crafting system to boot! The story, despite being well fleshed out from what I can see by the large amounts of text to be found around the abandoned facility, feels at times it could have been woven into the game a bit better. Still, it's a solid winner in my book ^_^
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Of all the games I've played on Steam and the many before it, few have instilled the kind of anxiety and jumpiness (dare I say fear?) that Teleglitch has. I hark back to Half Life 1, or my childhood experience of Doom 1. That's the kind of tension that Teleglitch builds. Just when you let your guard down, a swarm of zombies pours out of a pipe. Doors will unexepectedly open and deadly enemies start gunning you down.

It is permadeath and unforgiving, which makes it all that more tense as you progress. Just when you think you've gotten the hang of it, it throws a boss at you. It has been years since I have actually dreaded boss encounters - not since I was a kid. Teleglitch got to me in that way once again.

The screenshots don't do justice to the game as the graphics look a lot better in motion; the game is atmospheric with effectively done lighting and its gritty consistent style has enough detail to spur the imagination. Once you are drawn in then this is edge of your seat stuff - you are missing out while you don't own it.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

Resource management, crafting and gear customization in the style of System Shock.

reviewText: I play this game too much.\nTeleglitch DME is a kind of randomly generated rougelike game, in which you will die. A lot. No seriousley, I have put in over 20 hours into this game and I still haven't gotten to level 6 yet. (it's those goddam war walkers in level 5 that always kill me!) (Edit: After 36 hours I've gotten to level 7 twice. Was insta killed by a squid 10/10)calling this game hard is an understatement. It's like if you took that one impossible game" flash thing that was popular on the internet BUT ADDED GUNS!!!! Well not really... If you want to know how hard it is
date: it might have been updated but last time I checked 1.2 % of all teleglitch players have actually beaten the game. Give those guys an award!\n\nanyways
recommended: lets break the game down!\n\nLEVEL DESIGN: if i had to rate the level design id rate it a 7/10. It's the same rooms with the same chests but in a diffrent order and diffrent item placing. Notice the word placing. On level 1 you will always find (if you explore everything) 2 medkits that will revive 50 % of your health
hoursPlayed: a shotgun
voteText: a sticky grenade launcher
helpfulPercent: a bunch of canned meat
votesHelpful: and MMMMM BOMBS (cdi refrence). Some people find this repetative but in my opinion
votesTotal: if the game was really
votesFunny: REALLY randomly generated with diffrent items and new rooms
commentsCount: IT WOULD BE IMPOSSIBLE! Knowing what items I get is a huge advantage! I guess what I'm saying is I dont care if people say it's repetative
column16: I LOVE IT.\nwhen and if you beat level 1 (around 38 % actually do
column17:
but it's not that hard in my opinion. I beat level 1 on my first try!) you will come across 2 teleporters. One goes to a path that has an easier level with poopy items and then a BALLS TO THE WALLS HARD ONE proceeding to level 5. The other is just two really hard levels but with better items proceeding to level 5. Choices are good right? I personally love this gimmick as it affects my run depending on which I chose... Except now I dont choose because I know which I like.

SOUND AND MUSIC music!: there is none.
one of the cons to this game is there is no music. If the game had good music it would make the game waaaay more stressful. Running down a hallway into an open room wen suddenly: AHHHHHHHH A SQUIIIIIID!!!!!!! Just kidding! Ive never seen a squid in my entire 20 hours. Edit: After 30 hours I finally found a squid and killed it. Yay! Double Edit: The DLC adds music that isn't working... Yet. I've heard the devs are working on it.
The sound effects are pretty good. The gun noises sound pretty realistic
column18: and the noises the mutants make is pretty creepy.\n\nVISUALS i know totalbiscut mentions this in his review
column19: but the graphics have improved since he played it. DO NOT LET HIS REVIEW TURN YOU AWAY! Shading is better with shadows looking more "real" and in DME the menu is waaaaaaaay better. Something totalbiscut did say that is still true are how the guns feel. They feel like you're firing bullets instead of just a point in front of you that damages your enemies like in some FPS games. But what's even better are the bombs. When i first played the game I did with headphones. I threw a bomb and when it exploded I BLINKED! And I blinked the next 20 bombs or so as well! The explosion combined with the sound made me feel like something might hit my eye SO I BLINKED! I love the bombs in this game
column20: they're even cooler than the guns.\n\nGAMEPLAY/CONTROLS you move with WASD but can change it
column21: you shoot by holding right click then left clicking. Why? Well if you just normally left click you use a knife. Its pretty clever. Gameplay consists of running around
column24: and beng rewarded for exploring with items... Or monsters. It has a risk/reward system that keeps you on edge and when you find something good makes you be like "sweet!" You repeat this until you find a teleporter or die. Wait
column25:
this sound a ot like binding of issac now that i think about it...

OTHER THINGS I FORGOT TO SAY THAT ARE GOOD heres a list

crafting- there are so many options you have to make decisions whether to make this or that.

items/weapons- huge diversity. Theres like 100 or so diffrent items total and all are useful.

monsters- same as items but not useful. very
column26: VERY not useful. Also theres only like 20 but its still awesome.\n\nstory- not the main focus of the game
column27:
but you find little bunches of info here and there to piece together and find out what happened. Really good.

glitches- only came across one glitch but it made me rage so hard! I was about to get to level 5 for the first time and i got stuck at a text box. Edit: Happened to me again twice: Once in the tutorial while teaching a friend how to play and once on level 6 when I was about to get to level 7 for the first time >:c

OVERALL this game is really fun. 9/10"

reviewText: I like the atmosfhere when I first time start the game. But it become repetetive only after 10 or 15 minutes. recommended: in second run I get no more than 20 (I known that rogelike is based on randomness

voteText: that your run is unplayable becasuse of the lack of ammo)\n- I died at least twice in a way I cannot control/affect - bunch of enemies just run at me

and then 4 items back (maybe there are some shortcusts but I didnt look - you can move items in your inventory but it do not help much)

reviewText: It may not have Crysis-level graphics, but what matters is the gameplay. The tension of the unknown, the joy of finding a new gun or a medkit, the fear when you're low on health and ammo, is fantastic. When you enter a room armed with only two shotgun rounds, 25 health, and one explosive, and a horde of mutants and zombies rush out of the area where you can't see and you just turn and flee the other way...it's worth every penny.\n\nYou're always at a disadvantage. Every weapon, every piece of equipment counts. Every decision is life or death

reviewText:
I personally dont recommend it, it isn't partcularly a bad game, but the fact that you need to complete level 1,2,3,4,5 just to unlock the shortcut to level 3!

Anyway, the game itself is very unique, and actually fun, until you die over and over and over again and need to restart from level 1 if you didn't complete level 5 yet.

there is i assume 14 levels, or 12, not sure, but the game is short, if you can survive, but surviving is very hard. If you can't survive even 1 level, then this game will take ages to finish, because as i said, you start from the start or almost from the start because this game wants you to progress so much for a shortcut

TL;DR the game is unique and good, if you tend to do well in hard roguelike's then you will love this game, but if not, buy it at your own risk, it might not be entertaining for people who is bad in roguelike's (like me).

reviewText:
Dark souls:Die More Edition

Teleglitch:DIE MORE EDITION

A roguelike topdown shooter with randomly generated levels and references from the 80s, the game can get scary at some times.

Oh, and this game is hard.
Oh, and this game is brutal.
Oh, god, it's harder than dark souls.
This is such a bundle of tears, and fun.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Really didnt like this game, it seemed okay at first once you got over how incredibly crappy it all looks, not to mention the enemies that just looked like jumbled up pixels with a certain amount of legs, the random map generator was alright at making slightly uniqiue map layouts but its crappy gameplay and lack of items just made it boring and its lack of creativity left me feeling disappointed. Its storyline and little facts about the game were boring and hard to read in the pixelated text it uses. having to complete 5 levels before being able to save the game is just lame and ruins the whole fun of the game, overall I felt this game didnt offer enough to make me want to keep playing over the same maps versing the same units, getting up to level 4 and spawning next to a room filled with the strongest enemies who immediatly swarm you and murder you making you have to go back to level 1 and work your way through a pixelated nightmare of repetition. 2/10

reviewText:
Unlike other games of its kind, Teleglitch does not propose amazing soundtracks or nice pixels. But it's probably one that goes straight to the point.
It's hard, very hard, you can call it the Dark Souls of Indy games since you won't succeed easily. Moreover, the atmosphere is creepy and somehow scary.
Background is rather interesting and content is huge: plenty of items to craft and combine so that your equipment fits to your play style and monsters.
Get it!

reviewText: Teleglitch, a top down shooter where you kill aliens, zombies, spider looking creatures and much more. In this game you can use your fists, a gun, or even bombs (if you find them). If you kill the creatures you do have the possibility to get canned meat which increases your health and also a better chance at surviving the section. The goal of this game is to survive the section without dieing, if you die you have to restart section you are on. But after completing the all the sections within that level you can do other levels that you can do. The best thing about this game is that it supports a controller because lets face it... the controls on a keyboard are pretty horrible in the game. The art style is cool and a good game to waste a good hour on.

reviewText:
Fantastic top-down rogue-like shooter.

PROS:
- Atmospheric
- Hard difficulty
- Satisfying gunplay
- Effective use of pixel art
- Weapon and item crafting
- Simple yet intuitive interface
- Low price, high replay value

CONS:
- Easy to misselect weapons and items during intense combat
- Easy to run out of ammunition if not careful
- Permadeath can cause serious frustration
- Few ammunition crafting possibilities
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Died because of the ugly brown senseless pixellated art style disguising an insta-death trap rather than running low on resources and getting mobbed by hundreds of flesh-eating beasties in the height of hardcore survival deaths.

Not exactly what was advertised.

The next time I died because one shapeless blob enemy not all that different from the others suddenly started shooting at me and I learned pretty quick that my character doesn't take any more bullets than the enemies do.

Naturally, I could not make out that he had a gun and was about to fire. Nor had I the components for armor by then.

More to the point, Teleglitch isn't bad. It just isn't good. The game revels in the old System Shock 2 pacing with loads of stuff to collect and fiddle with all bouncing around your inventory, but just like System Shock 2, there's a lot of time consuming fiddle and very little in the way of meaningful decisions there. A bunch of crafting components but only one or two clearly useful items to build. Oh, I could make my gun fire twice as many bullets? In a game where ammo is scarce and accuracy is essential? Next you'll offer me an upgrade for that awful knife at the cost of all my cans.

Unlike SS2, this game is actually hard. Combat is brutal and quick. You don't die fast (except for when you do) so it plays to a long haul survival, which I like. Problem is, it's the sort of game you need to repeat over and over and have a wiki open in the other window until you finally manage that perfect run and it just isn't fun enough to carry the game. It has the worst collectathon inventory fiddle of SS2 mixed with the same combat we've seen since Crimsonland and Nation Red only with higher stakes and nothing else that makes those games interesting. The first couple of swarms are fun but once you fight the same swarm a dozen times it's a bit tiresome.

The graphic design is ugly ugly UGLY UGLY! There's no charm in these wretched pixel blobs, which kills any atmosphere of survival dead. The levels themselves bring just as little to the table as the graphics. Big room, room, hallway, room, room with loot, swarm room, ooh loot? no another friggen text log etc etc. This normally wouldn't be bad but the whole game is conspiring to be as charmless and plodding as possible and wants to drag out your time with it with so much repetition so every one of these faults ends up magnified.

reviewText:
Fantastic top-down rogue-like shooter.

PROS:
- Atmospheric
- Hard difficulty
- Satisfying gunplay
- Effective use of pixel art
- Weapon and item crafting
- Simple yet intuitive interface
- Low price, high replay value

CONS:
- Easy to misselect weapons and items during intense combat
- Easy to run out of ammunition if not careful
- Permadeath can cause serious frustration
- Few ammunition crafting possibilities

reviewText:
Died because of the ugly brown senseless pixellated art style disguising an insta-death trap rather than running low on resources and getting mobbed by hundreds of flesh-eating beasties in the height of hardcore survival deaths.

Not exactly what was advertised.

The next time I died because one shapeless blob enemy not all that different from the others suddenly started shooting at me and I learned pretty quick that my character doesn't take any more bullets than the enemies do.

Naturally, I could not make out that he had a gun and was about to fire. Nor had I the components for armor by then.

More to the point, Teleglitch isn't bad. It just isn't good. The game revels in the old System Shock 2 pacing with loads of stuff to collect and fiddle with all bouncing around your inventory, but just like System Shock 2, there's a lot of time consuming fiddle and very little in the way of meaningful decisions there. A bunch of crafting components but only one or two clearly useful items to build. Oh, I could make my gun fire twice as many bullets? In a game where ammo is scarce and accuracy is essential? Next you'll offer me an upgrade for that awful knife at the cost of all my cans.

Unlike SS2, this game is actually hard. Combat is brutal and quick. You don't die fast (except for when you do) so it plays to a long haul survival, which I like. Problem is, it's the sort of game you need to repeat over and over and have a wiki open in the other window until you finally manage that perfect run and it just isn't fun enough to carry the game. It has the worst collectathon inventory fiddle of SS2 mixed with the same combat we've seen since Crimsonland and Nation Red only with higher stakes and nothing else that makes those games interesting. The first couple of swarms are fun but once you fight the same swarm a dozen times it's a bit tiresome.

The graphic design is ugly ugly UGLY UGLY! There's no charm in these wretched pixel blobs, which kills any atmosphere of survival dead. The levels themselves bring just as little to the table as the graphics. Big room, room, hallway, room, room with loot, swarm room, ooh loot? no another friggen text log etc etc. This normally wouldn't be bad but the whole game is conspiring to be as charmless and plodding as possible and wants to drag out your time with it with so much repetition so every one of these faults ends up magnified.

reviewText: Ok this was a very interesting game. The name says: Die More. Well, you won't die more, you will die MUCH more. I had 130 hours in Dark Souls and as many in Dark Souls 2, but both game were EASY compared to the stress level this one gives. You may never know what is behind a corner. Problem is, you will never respawn nor have a save to repeat that place. In fact, the levels are random. If in Dark Souls you would know the level by memory after some deaths, here you just experience a new level every time you die. And you die a lot. There are some 'checkpoints' meaning that if you reach a certain level (there are 10 levels) you have the possibility to start from 2 levels before (e.g. reach level 5? you can then start from the 3rd without having to start all over from the first). That sounds easy, but I was literally not able to reach level 7 (and thus be able to start from level 5).\n\n6 Hours in this game is not a lot at all. I guess to really be able to complete the game you have to spend much more. And die much more than I did. I liked the game a lot, but it simply needs a concentration and patience I do not have in these days. I have lots of games to play, and not so much free time so I'll have to pass on this demanding and almost stressful title. Maybe I will play it again in the future. In the meantime, I can only recommend this particular game, I cannot compare it to anything else, it reminded me a bit of the difficulties encountered in the Dark souls games, but it still is VERY different obviously. 85/100 would be my rating, despite having played it not that long. It is surely a nice little gem. Have fun with it (or have none, lol).

reviewText:
Perfect little game with interesting story and graphics. But it is difficult to a point where it becomes pure torture to play it.

I love these top down shooters, and I don't mind that games are hard.
But this one is just plain stupidly difficult.

I could probably live with the fact that there is no save option, and that death is permanent if it was only per level. But the game requires you to get to level 5, to be able to start from level 3.
This takes something like at least half an hour. No matter how good a game is, I don't like to spend that amount of time, just to make a little mistake, and then having to restart.

Some people will tell you that it's the purpose of the game to be that difficult. But gameplay wise there is no logic to that. Beating this game could give you bragging rights, but really it's as stupid as bragging about Wow guys! Yesterday I finally managed to roll a dice and get a six
date:
ten times in a row... cool eh?"


The game actually tells a funny story and has some interesting stuff going on. But most players will never get past level 3... so most of it is lost.

It's a d**n shame that the developers decided: "F**k it... I don't want to create more content. Instead I'll just ramp up the difficulty so it takes weeks to beat the game anyway."


The truth is that most people will feel cheated if they pay for this game... so I can not recommend it.
"

reviewText: Teleglitch is a neat game with a good concept. I really like the top-down gameplay and the atmosphere of the game (reminds me of a 2D version of Dead Space), but I'm left with a bad taste in my mouth due to the extreme difficulty. Can there be a Die Less Edition?? The player is quickly swarmed with very fast moving enemies, and the player has very limited resources which creates tons of deaths. I was able to complete Level 1 but upon dying on Level 2 numerous of times I'm always forced to restart at the beginning of Level 1! I need to reach Level 5 in order to unlock and start at Level 3; looking at the Steam Achievements only ~20% of the game owners have even beat Level 2 which just shows the absurd difficulty the game puts players through. I wish there was an option to make the game more casual" for those who just want to enjoy the story/atmosphere and not go through a tedious grind of replaying the levels over and over just to progress a small amount before having to repeat."

reviewText:
After dying over and over and over again in this permadeath game that is extremely hard for the wrong reasons, I gave up and am done with it. I just died on level 4 because I went into a room and two big zombies and three little ones were right against the door and two shooters were in the room and I had 75 health and no kits and died in about 2 seconds. And that is considering that it takes a incredible amount of luck to get to level 5 so you can permanently unlock the ability to start the game from level 3. Which is a bad idea anyway because when you start from a higher level at a later date, you keep none of your supplies. So basically, you absolutely have to do this game in one run. What makes the game so bad are a few things. First is that they expect you to navigate a list of ten or more items in the game while backpedaling from enemy swarms. It is very difficult because of the unnecessarily large variety of guns and bombs and food. It could have been somewhat easier had there simply been a few less different items to navigate. You can drop nailbombs and what not to blow up a pack of zombies while you run away, but you have to be extremely careful or it kills you too. Normally this all would be great, but the real game killer in my opinion are two things. One is hitboxes. They are very tiny. To shoot an enemy with your pistol you have to hit it directly in the head twice to kill. A body shot and your bullets pass through it without damaging it. I frequently find myself taking more than 2 shots to kill something and wasting my ultra scarce ammo because of the biggest flaw in the game which is the only real reason that it is so extremely difficult: enemy sliding and circle-stepping around you. I have seen it in many other games in my lifetime and I am not sure why developers do it. It is when an enemy gets close to you and melee attacks you but you can't land any shots or melee hits of your own because it magically circle floats around you while hitting you, draining tons of your life. This one is doubly upsetting because enemies also walk towards you in a slightly wobbly pattern, which combined with their very small one millimeter hitboxes, make it unbelievably frustrating.

The only thing I liked about this game were the graphics. They are vomit inducing blurry Atari 2600 graphics to most, but I found that it works alright for this particular game. Considering that it is a cheap game, I am perfectly happy just forgetting about it and playing one of the other 140+ great games that I have installed right now. I do not have to have anything else to do with this game to prove my gaming skills. I have beat some of the hardest games of all-time because they did not have poor hitboxing and float circling from enemies, two hallmarks of a poorly made game.

This game is a rare example of one that does not deserve the high praise that it got from some reviewers, but amazingly somehow ppl like it. I don't get it because I have had an easier time beating harder but much better programmed games.

reviewText:
I'm already done with playing this game, so what can I say about it?

Pros
-I got it free
-Steam Cards

Cons
-The camera view changes too often (zooming in/out and rotating)(also effects maps view) and complicates some fights.
-I died once for no reason at all, not a single monster around.
-Randomized maps may seem fun, but the backtracking isn't.
-AI is horrid (I'm talking straight line targetting, an AI system which can be implemented with very few lines of code).

In the end perhaps this could be an enjoyable game for some, but at the normal price it's just not worth it. Sadly I can't give any more pro's because I just don't care to play any further, those cons killed it for me way too fast.

reviewText:
Doom meets Dark Souls via System Shock 2, in 1990 - atmospheric, stunningly challenging combat roguelike in a science fiction horror setting, exploring and surviving an abandoned military research and development facility on a quarantined planet. Craft weapons from the junk you scavenge from these rusting hallways and hold off the horde of reactivated dead soldiers, designed combat mutants and mechanical war machines.

Well worth the money and easy to run on almost any computer, this game has consistently entertained me since the first version was released in late 2012, and this version has expanded the content and variety of gameplay by a mile.

Follow me. Escape Medusa 1-C.

Conclusion: If you want a game to stay in your library it's worth the money.You won't play the game more than 2 hours then you will leave it there.If it doesnt start... well you will play the demo version and wait 1 year or 2 for the developer to fix the problem."

reviewText:
I was so excited when I saw Teleglitch on Humble for free, I remember seeing a youtube personality review it a while back and I had completely forgotten about it. Boy was I upset when I launched the game only to find it was totally unplayable.
I know this game works, and I think it’s probably pretty fun from the little bit I’ve seen of the gameplay, but when I try to run it it microstutters almost constantly and every 3-4 seconds the rendering freezes entirely for a few seconds then rapidly catches up. I have tried everything, every setting, every resolution, verified the game cache multiple time, if it could have an effect on performance I’ve tinkered with it. The game is blatantly not resource intensive yet there is some serious issue with my hardware setup.
I think it’s probably a good game, but buyer beware that there are some rare compatibility issues.

i7 2600k
GTX 680
8 Gb 1600 Mhz for ram
850 W PSU
Everything installed on SSD
Z77 Sabertooth Mobo

reviewText:
Teleglitch didn't hold my notice for more than an hour.  The procedurally generated world isn't that diverse.  After 20 minutes, I noticed the same layout's from a game a few minutes prior.  I understand rogue likes are supposed to be hard, but this one just isn't that fun to play.  I was initially using a gamepad then switched to kb&m and found the latter works MUCH better.  You need the sensitivity of a mouse for aiming.

The developers tried to go with a Doom like vibe with this top down shooter.  I felt like I was playing Doom 3 but in a retro, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ parody of it.  You will go through so many doors and hallways that look the same.  The shooting is the most demanding thing from this game.  You have to learn how to stay ahead of your target or you will miss most of the time.  Ammo is also extremely scarse on some playthrough's making your fists the weapon of choice in the first level to conserve ammo.

Ultimately, it's a repeptive rogue like shooter that doesn't hold my attention for more than an hour at a time.  It's good if you want to waste 20 minutes before you go to work.  If there were some character development or upgrades you could do in between deaths, it would add longevity to the very repetitive gameplay.  Luckily, I got this game for just over $1.  When I saw that this game was 13 bucks I LOL'd.

reviewText: Don't be fooled by Teleglitch - what looks like something capturing the old spirit of DooM from a top-down perspective turned out to be a mostly annoying/frustrating experience for me.\n\nMastery of the controls is a requirement, precision a must. Failure will be punished with permadeath. The controller-support doesn't deliver, and unfortunately Teleglitch is not build to be an arcade-ish twinstick-shooter and kind of resembles Dead Nation" in it's approach to aiming/shooting. If I had to compare the "gamefeel" of shooting and aiming to something I would say it's a top-down Counterstrike
date: clad in a DooM-like setting (no blasphemous hellspawn around though) with rather unnecessary crafting/survival-horror thrown in for good measure. A mix that might be appealing to some
recommended: but certainly isn't for me.\n\nI did however enjoy reading the various text-files and logs - the lore and setting works just fine. And the general art-direction is very cool
hoursPlayed: with added scanlines this game is quite nicely looking despite the somewhat 8-Bit style used and a lot of subtle visual effects add a nice touch to these big chunky pixels. It's just a shame the rest isn't as convincing - might be a case of wrong expectations on my part
voteText: but this game is lacking the "arcade-style" quality that I am looking for in top-down games."

reviewText:
Avoid! My recommendation is to avoid it even at the 75% discount cost, which feels about full price for something like this(Hint: This is a 0.99$ game you get in a bundle).

This game is Hack, Slash, Loot under a different coat of paint so if you did for some reason love HSL then by all means pick this one up. For those who don't know what HSL is, It's a rogue-like, but without any of the tricks and strategy that goes into beating other rogue-likes. In other rogue-likes you might die because you got careless, forgot something or just didn't know any better, but H,S,L will kill you just because F@#% You, it's a terrible game that can be summed up with just a few words, unfun RNG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

Back to this game. There is no playing smart, no strategizing with this one, you either have a gun with ammo or you don't because you couldn't find one, but too bad about not finding one because the mobs running at you don't care. The only way to progress though this game is to bash your head against a brick wall over and over again until the RNG smiles down upon you and you some how managed to make it past the level 1-5 floors you kept dying on and you got past level 5, which now lets you start at level 3, repeat head bashing over and over again for floors 3-7 until the RNG smiles on you and you somehow manage to beat level 7 which will let you start a new game at level 5 this time, repeat once again for floors 5-9 and 7-10 until you can finally beat level 10 and finish this POS.

It also auto deletes saves because it's a rogue-like and we can't allow save scumming in a single player game, which is fine I guess but unfortunately the game has crashed on me twice now after beating a level which has deleted my save, so you might also want to consider holding off until some bug fixing patches first.

It's an incredibly shallow rogue-like, and after an hour of play you'll feel like you've basically seen everything the game has to offer save some special bosses. At 3.25$ (never mind the laughable 12.99 regular price, holy ♥♥♥♥ what were they thinking) it's just to much to ask for, for this copy/paste floor design for 10 levels game that adds a ton of aggravating ♥♥♥♥ to it that makes it overall unfun to play, just like with H,S,L.

Buy a good cup of coffee instead.

reviewText:
I really REALLY wanted to like this game.  I love the way it looks and I enjoy the actual gameplay.  I thrive on difficulty and challenge.  This game, however, is not falsely advertising.  You will die more.  The game will literally never give you what you need to survive more than 2 or three levels.  Maybe I'm just getting too old for this, but the amount of dying I was doing without gaining any skills was too frusterating.  Which would be okay, but it's really not fun to die on level one 50 times in a row and not be given the tools to survive.

I'm not saying it's a bad game.  But it's sure not for me.  I wish I could give my copy away so maybe someone else can enjoy it, because I don't even want to own this game anymore.

[EDIT]
After the new rebalancing patch I have to change my tune.  This game now has a more appropriate difficulty curve that is both challenging, and encourages improvment and continued gameplay by letting you get past the first couple levels with less death-swarms, and more resources.

I'd like to thank the developers for making me feel like I spent money on a game I can now enjoy much more consitently.

reviewText:
Got this for free and I cannot believe people paid money for this game. The entire production feels like a student project more than anything.  I'm sorry, but a decent student project doesn't make for a good commerical game.

Teleglitch is a clunky twin stick shooter with the pretensions of a roguelike. The worst parts of being a roguelike,with the uneven difficulty making it boring until  the seconds before you die and you have to repeat, and repeat, and repeat.  The basic shooting/combat mechanic is passable but movement through the levels is a chore since you have no idea what the hell you are looking at. There seems to be some kind of deep meta game with a cool variety of weapons, items, and enemies.  It's too bad it all ends up being pointless window dressing because the basic gameplay loop is so unsatisfying.

Graphics wise the enemies are very generic retro pixel art, and there is not much you can do wrong or right with a single pixel for each limb.  It is not an exaggeration to say that Robotron in 1982 had more detailed characters.  The shadows swinging around to show line of sight are obnoxious and distracting.

The backgrounds and levels however are godawful.  The color palletes and mystery blobs make each level a modern art puzzle smeared over a low resolution pixel canvas.  Is that a door, a table, a wall, a gun, a plant, a light, a rug, a dead body, a crate, or a brown lump?  Can I interact with it or move through it? The graphics certainly won't tell you, so you will have to memorize it through one of your 50 plays through the same area.  A more elegant minimalist approach to the backgrounds would have suited this kind of game much better.

reviewText: This game is awfully designed.\n\nLevels 1 and 2 are easy enough, but level 3 is incredibly hard, with enemies that can 3 shot you with fast pistol attacks, and surprise mobs.  There is technically a level 3 checkpoint, but you don't actually get to use the checkpoint until you make it to level 5.  Most people won't even get past level 3, so that checkpoint" is worthless
date: again because people won't even make it to level 4 (and 5 to actually trigger the checkpoint)\n\nThere's no "easy" mode
recommended: so you have no opportunity to practice to learn how to fight the hard enemies.  You have to slog through 20 minutes of lvl 1 & 2 again before you get the privilege of dying in seconds to the hard enemies on level 3.\n\nA strong pass."

reviewText:
Telleglitch: Die More Edition

Well, I have to say I was somewhat dissapointed with this game, honestly there isn't much to say about it. Some games are really bad, but they have personality, a vibe about them you can describe and assign. A REASON for being bad. this game is like a black hole. I don't know why its so bad, maybe it's the frustrating combat system, bland story, even more bland art style and boring audio... Or the fact that no matter how far you progress, if you die, its game over. Which although I understand the total restart feature isn't really an absolute bad thing, it's very frustrating. The levels are long and difficult, so why not give the player a checkpoint of some sorts SOMEWHERE in the game.

Maybe I'm just not the type of person that understands what this game is really trying to offer to me, but I can tell you it wasn't worth the money for me. If you really want to get it, get it on sale...

Great game! Has a chilling atmosphere with permanent death, limited ammo, a spooky environment, and many ambushes.

Checkpoints take a lot of effort to get to. EX- first checkpoint is at lvl 3, and the lvl 5 checkpoint requires getting to lvl 7
Multiplayer! PLEASE ADD MULTIPLAYER! :O

Overall a pretty good game, however enyone but seasoned veterans will have quite a difficult time.

reviewText: I've only played it for a couple of hours so far but I find it addictive. It's in no way forgiving and you'll DIE A LOT but really that makes it challenging and thus fun! Sure it's frustrating, but the levels randomly rearrange after each restart so that avoids it becoming stale. The monsters are fast and tricky and aiming it quite a challenge at first, but you'll pick up on it. There is a simple game toggle to allow for random gear on start, which can help, or in some cases leave you with no weapon, only a cool piece of gear and a bomb to start; making the challenge all the greater! IMO so far, this is a fun challenge...if you're EVEN UP TO IT!!!

reviewText: BUY IT, OKAY?\n\nGuns feel satisfying, atmosphere is intense, even inventory management has depth and crafting. Everything about this game screams quality.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Pros:
-Simplistic, pixel art style that scratches the old-school itch for gaming graphics. Sound design also adds to the old-school feeling with it's pixelated beeps and bleeps. Not to mention, adds to the creepy factor of the game.

-Well thought-out and interesting story and lore content.  You could think of it sort of being like Half-life with a much darker tone and takes a few cues from Doom.

-levels are open, big and change layout per play through. You will never see the same route twice.

-You always feel encouraged to explore for loot and lore in a level even if the exit is nearby.

-Gameplay is simple top-down point and shooting action mixed with  survival-horror elements. But that doesn't mean the game is a breeze to play through. The crafting is to the point and easy to use, you won't have to look up a wiki article to find an item recipe.

-Enemy AI can pose a challenge. They aren't some mindless targets that simply jump out and run towards you awaiting to be gunned down. They will actually try to dodge your shots and move on your blindspots to attack.


Cons: (Though you could argue this is more of a personal annoyance than flaws.)

-While the game's difficulty is refreshing and will keep you on your toes, it can have it's fair share of annoyances.  Like the checkpoint system. This game is very strict in marking your level progress, it will only make a checkpoint after you complete a bulk of the levels at a time.

But because of the steep difficulty curve in the gameplay, death is inenvitable. You're going to die sooner or later. And when you do, unless you unlocked a checkpoint recently, you go back to the last one you unlocked which was WAY back in the levels.  Some cases even going back to the start of the game.

This gets extremely aggravating when you have to play level one three times just because you died on level four and have to play the same levels over and over again to get back where you left off. However on the other hand, the game would probably lose some difficulty if there was a more forgiving checkpoint system. So I guess it's more about having patence with the game.

Overall, Teleglitch is a well-made shooter that accomplished what it set out to do. It doesn't do anything ground-breaking but goes on what it knows best. It's fun, challenging, and quite lengthy with annoyances such as a checkpoint system that is a little too strict for my taste.  But to each his own.

reviewText:
There is so much about this game that I really like:

The simplistic style is super good, and the dark atmosphere and the generated sightlines are 100% on point. The darkness really adds...uncertainty, as better words fail me.

The inventory system is so intuitive and simple, and does not even interrupt gameplay in the slightest. Honestly, it actually feels like I'm the one in the game moving ♥♥♥♥ around, and that seems completly bizarre because all it is is a list of text on the left side of the screen. It's oddly immersive.

I love the enemies - not because that they're super smart, or they have lore attached to them stowed away on various computers around the level, but their mutated-pixelated forms make you conjure up in your imagination what they would actually look like, given the rather horrifying information for said tid-bits of information you're gathered on them.

Haven't played much at the time of writing this, but that will soon be remedied.

Best thing Humble Bundle has ever given me for free.

reviewText:
Surprisingly under-the-radar and punishing as all ♥♥♥♥ing hell. Not for the faint of heart, you will die, die often, die again, and then uninstall the game until you decide to reinstall days later so you can attempt another run.

I still haven't gotten past level four.

The game relies on learning your enemies' patterns, experimenting with weapon crafting, conserving ammo, crafting materials, health supplies and praying desperately the room you just entered doesn't have the next thing that will end your run. It's all skill, no perks, no frills. Luck, skill, persistence.

Also has one of the best achievements ever; Death Pudding Matador"."

reviewText:
Teleglitch is a game which pushes roguelikes into real time quite well. A departure from the typical turn based roguelikes (which I do enjoy), there's an additional element of action, forcing you to act without having any time to plan your actions.

The story is pretty typical with an experiment gone wrong, with the facility gone to hell. Aside from the monologue between levels, terminals are scattered through the randomly generated areas, with small bits and pieces to inform you of the various devices in the game, as well as things you can do to make your life more manageable.

Graphically, this game does well. Without attempting to try and make the graphics realistic, the pixel style is a nice step up from the grid-based tile setup, and the lighting flickers to just show the outline of the enemies ahead.

The sounds are minimalistic, and the eery silence will make you strain to listen out for any of the encounters that could be lurking in the shadows. Weapons sound the way you'd imagine, although they are a vast contrast to when you're not in combat.

Gameplay in Teleglitch is challenging and unforgiving, layering pressure with every level as you struggle to manage materials, deal with the enemies, and escape from the current sector.

Paradox recently released a new patch which added an arena mode which allows you to get into the action much quicker. With different loadouts, you can take on multitudes of enemies with items you probably didn't know existed. It however can get repetitive as the required objectives are fairly standard and tend to loop over and over. They are also limited by the fact that you can only unlock arenas after reaching a level from the main game.

You might play this game once, and forget it for a while. But do come back to it. You might escape after all.

reviewText:
I was walking down a courtyard and began to squeeze through a crack in the wall, I came into a small room covered in pipes and oil drums, I suddenly heard the screech of a zombie, i backed my way through the small opening in the wall i came in through and pulled out my revolver. I watched as one by one zombies began pouring out of one of the pipes. I began to open fire hoping that the small crack would funnel them into my bullets. There was too many, so i placed an explosive at the end of the hallway and switched to my shotgun. The explosion went off and bits of zombie flew every which way, but there was still more. Firing on them with the wider cone of fire of the shotgun backed my way through the courtyard. Suddenly doors glided open and mutants filled the room. I became surrounded and died.

Pros:
1. Sound(Hearing the hum and chirp of the machines, and skittering of enemies queing you to begin a gun fight).
2. The Menu System
-You can easily sort items on the fly
-Craft a ♥♥♥♥ ton of helpful items( Make your 9mm an auto, create a device that can detect enemie mobs, jury rig a can gun which is basically an explosive put into an empty can of meat.)
3. The Farther you go in, the crazier the enemies get
4. Secret rooms
5. Field of vision makes the exploration extra tense
Cons:
1. It can be confusing at times where to go to advance
2. The graphics

reviewText:
Teleglitch is a retro pixelated roguelike survival top-down shooter with zombies. In other words, it’s a perfect storm of indie game clichés. But it proves that it’s lack of imagination, or flawed execution, that makes a bad game out of those clichés.

I can’t explain exactly why, but Teleglitch perfectly captures the feeling I remember of playing DooM for the first time as a kid in the mid-90s. That is to say, it’s absolutely nothing like the DooM I actually played, and everything like the DooM I remember. To me, that’s the absolute best kind of retro.

The exact mix of those indie game clichés is part of what allows Teleglitch to deliver that DooM-like experience. Randomly/procedurally-generated rooms keep everything fresh, so you’re always encountering rooms for the first time, with no idea what lurks in the corners. The scarcity of ammo and health means you have to worry about every shot. And the way the enemies accelerate as they get closer to you makes the back-pedaling panic that much more intense. And the walls actually extend upwards toward the camera, creating a really interesting variation on the top-down perspective.

But the wealth of terrible games using a similar mix of elements suggests there’s more to Teleglitch’s evoking of the first-time DooM experience. I can’t put my finger on exactly what it is, but I like it.

http://macrotransactions.wordpress.com/2013/10/09/200-games-200-words-10-teleglitch/

reviewText: What I happened to love on Teleglitch: Die More Edition is how it leaves a vast space for your imagination to fill in the story. The story itself is served to you via text and text only. I have seen thre universes in the game. 1) Doom. Yes, it reminds me of 2D Doom, except for you are not an ultimate badass chainsawing through hordes of deamons without a single drop of sweat. 2) Far Rainbow by Boris and Arakdy Strugatsky (Russian sci-fi authors, creators of Stalker), where the teleportation experiments caused the destruction of the planet they took place on. And finally, 3) Strontium by Jiří Kulhánek, Czech sci-fi author. This is due to failed experiments on dead people and the Luxor part in the book. Thanks to this I'm really enjoying the game, besides the game mechanics and pixelated graphics (yes, I actually like these too).\n\nDo I recommend Teleglitch: Die More Edition? Well, yes, I do, thanks for asking. If you don't mind reading, have a decent bit of imagination and feel like being a bit nostalgic time to time, go for it. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Teleglitch is a beautful game. No, really. Sure, you can count the number of pixels your character is made up of, but the simple, low-res style is compensated for by great lighting effects and clever use of line-of-sight, as well as a sense of nostalgia, mostly of DOS games. With it's top down shooter style reminiscent of Flash games, simple and intuitive controls and inventory and crafting system, the game world itself carries a highly atmospheric setting and a compelling story that you unlock piece by piece at computer terminals ingame. There's a great amount of tension and uncertainty as you shoot, salvage, sort your items and ultimately try to survive, unsure of how long you're going to last. The gameplay is very challenging but not overly unfair, and satisfying from the very start.\n\nNot a lot of roguelikes catch my interest but Teleglitch creates a gameplay experience that always stays fresh. Hats off to the developers, they've made an awesome game, and an awesome experience.

reviewText:
I awake in a storage closet after months of living off of nothing but what I can only describe as wet Cardboard preserved only by this metal encasing that misleadingly says 'Meat'. I have been emotionally and psycologically been pushed further than i ever thought a human being could withstand but despite all I have gone through I know I have to do something. I am not dying here without doing something. I pick myself up off the floor and step past the invisible line that sets off the motion sensor and the door opens; It's time to begin.

I step outside and try to find my bearings but nothing's the same. The Hallways have shifted, the once bustling control center is covered in different Growths. I try to identify some for different sustanence but to no avail; I know what these are, and there's no way I want to be around them much longer. These are part of the experiment sector C was working on, they were trying to biologically modify life forms for military applications, They asked my department to run some tests on these to see exactly what would be the benefits if they infused them with some sort of Mammal. They proved to have poisonous and acidic qualities. As I rememeber all those months ago I feel weak. I put my hand on a nearby table to support myself but it slips and I fall, I look to see what My hand slipped on and I see it's a small handgun. I pick it up and assure myself I won't need it but I take it nonetheless-For security. I tand up and venture down mislplaced hallways until I hear a voice coming from a Room nearby; I can't make out any words but I know I have to see who's there. I once more step past the invisible line to open the door and what I see I couldn't have possibly braced myself for.

There's a man Infused with the same plant life that I saw in the other room stroking the decaying corpse adonned with the same white coat I myself wore for years in this Facility. Although the creature isn't using his body at all; he's completely in control of the Vines that suspend his body in the air. The shock finally subsides when I realize that he hasn't noticed me yet and I reach for the Gun I Have tucked away in my belt. I reach around, as slow as I possibly can as not to draw attention. I feel my hand wrap around the cold metal, take a deep, silent breath, draw it in front of me and turn off the safety. But as I slide the top part back to chamber the bullet the gun may as well screamed as the click it produced caused the monster to drop the corpse, whip it's half-decayed Face at me and Scream 'DROP IT. DROP IT. DROP IT. DROP IT. DROP IT. DROP IT. DROP IT.' As it was chanting the command I nearly complied out of sheer terror but I stood my ground, Aimed and Fired. It recoiled and Released a scream of Agony right before it Charged at me with speed I'd never seen before, Chanting the same commands as it's old body was being dragged across the floor, leaving a red trail behind it. I shot at it until it stopped moving and my handgun was empty. I stared at the mangled, hole ridden clump of vines, blood, and slime until i was brought back into conciousness by a far too late echo of it's final scream that came from somewhere deeper in the facility. I know they're coming, and I need to prepare.

This Game is without a doubt, my Favorite Roguelike game I have ever played and it being free on Humble bundle is extremely lucky but I would definitely pay 15 dollars for this game.

reviewText: So I had been wanting Teleglitch for awhile. It's been in my wishlist for several months, but next to all the other games there, it wasn't really a priority of mine to get it. I thought, Well
date: that's a neat little game. Looks like fun." But other than that
recommended: I didn't think much more of it.\n\nAnd then PC Gamer posted an article about how the game was free with Humble Bundle. Like
hoursPlayed: literally free. Not "buy one get one free"
voteText: but actually free. So it only took me about 3 minutes of juggling with my e-mail
helpfulPercent: my Steam account and Humble Bundle in Chrome
votesHelpful: and BAM! Free game. How awesome is that? (You can get this game for free as well by putting your e-mail address into Humble Bundle's site
votesTotal: and then logging in to Steam and activating the game key. As long as you do it before the end of November 2014.) So that's cool! I got this $13 game for free. Something for nothing. Now for the review!\n\nTeleglitch is reminiscent of other roguelikes available on Steam like FTL and Binding of Isaac. One thing I like about the game is that the lore is actually revealed through walking up to computers in-game and accessing databases
votesFunny: which makes it feel like scanning terminals in Metroid Prime. Sounds are very precise and make you feel like you're actually in a desolate facility
commentsCount: and it feels very immersive. Unlocking lore
column16: killing enemies
column17: and crafting items will help you fill up your Info section which basically gives information and lore on specific aspects of the game. Once you kill an enemy
column18: your info will be updated permanently
column19: and you can view everything in a Risk of Rain monster log style layout.\n\nThe graphics and gameplay make Teleglitch feel kind of like a top-down Doom 3. It has a unique inventory and crafting system as well
column20: and although it took me a little while to figure out how to use it
column21: it actually is really important to craft things in order to survive. For instance
column22: you can combine RDX-250 (an explosive charge) with an empty can of meat that you just ate out of
column24: to create a one-shot-use weapon called the 'cangun' that explodes and sprays shrapnel in the face of your enemies. Pretty awesome. And there's plenty of other goodies you can craft besides that.\n\nThe combat system feels nice once you get the hang of it. It's fairly simple controls. WASD moves your character
column28: you can simply left-click without aiming to jab in front of you with a knife while a weapon is equipped. Your inventory is always open and off to the side
column29: so mousewheel up and down will select different items or weapons. Left-click will also use items if you have them selected instead of a weapon
column30: for instance using medkits or eating canned meat. Bombs and explosive charges work similarly. Simply left-clicking will drop them at your feet while holding right-click will aim and left-click will throw. Explosives have a very short fuse and will damage the player if he/she is too close. Overall
column31: fighting in the game is very fun
column32: but ammunition is typically scarce. This makes ammo conservation a must as the player struggles to manage resources. Hearing the telltale *Click* after pulling the trigger on a now-empty gun is never a fun sound when there's mutants and zombies hurtling towards you at running speed.\n\nOne thing that kinda surprised me and bummed me out is that there is
column34: no music in the game. It does make the game feel a bit creepier though
column35: not having a soundtrack to cover up the dead silence and occasional noise. But if you absolutely need music
column36: the developers have made a $2 "Guns and Tunes" DLC that adds music to the game as well as some additional guns. It's worth two bucks for a game like this. Alternatively
column37: you could probably play your own music in the background just as well.\n\nThe DLC actually doesn't update the game's files with the music
column38: which seemed kind of minimalist to me at first
column39: and confused me because after buying it there was still no music in the game. But as it turns out
column40: the music from the DLC instantly becomes available in your built-in Steam music player after buying. So what does this mean? Well
column41: all you have to do to listen to your music is open the Steam music player by right-clicking "Library" and then clicking on "Music". Then
column45: just like you would with any game. Put it on repeat and shuffle it if you want
column46: then you can go back to your games library and load up Teleglitch. It sounds inconvenient
column47: but it's actually not that bad at all.\n\nI really think I'm going to enjoy playing this game over the next few weeks
column50: and creepy enough that it's uncomfortable playing it alone in the dark at night. Teleglitch seems like it has a lot of potential for the surprisingly difficult rougelike game that it is. If you are able to get this game
column51: you would have to be hard pressed to not enjoy it."

The game punishes you if you aren't prepared. It also punishes you later in the game for wasting ammo, explosives, medkits, etc early on. I've completed an old version of the game and found that I didn't have to use the knife all that much. We'll see with this one.

It's great to see development of this game years after first release. It shows that the developers still care and they're rewarding fans past and present with more varied and enhanced (better sound effects, better lighting) gameplay. Unlike, say, nidhogg, which is my disappointment of the year.

If you're a masochist like me, you'll love this game.
